Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical Characterization of Functionalized Carbon Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Igor Vasiliev of New Mexico State University is supported by an award from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program for research focusing on theoretical characterization of functionalized carbon nanostructures. Prof. Vasiliev and his students will develop and apply state-of-the-art density functional and time-dependent density functional computational methodologies to study the mechanism of chemical functionalization of graphene and carbon nanotubes. The main objective of the proposed research is to investigate the relationship between the structural and electronic characteristics of carbon nanostructures and their reactivity toward organic and inorganic molecules and functional groups. This research will lead to a better understanding of the process of self-assembly of molecules and functional groups on the surface of graphene and carbon nanotubes.

This research will be beneficial for the development of experimental techniques that could be used for selective chemical functionalization of carbon nanostructures. The unique properties of carbon nanostructures such as graphene nanoribbons and carbon nanotubes make them promising candidates for a wide range of technological applications, including chemical sensors, fuel cells, photovoltaic cells, light emitting devices, nanoelectronics, and spintronics. The majority of these applications require the use of carbon nanostructures with very specific electronic and optical characteristics. The proposed theoretical study will analyze the possibility of using chemical functionalization as a method for separating different types of carbon nanostructures by selectively removing unwanted structures after synthesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon nanomaterials have attracted significant attention in recent years. The remarkable properties of carbon nanotubes, graphene, and graphene nanoribbons make them promising candidates for a variety of applications in electronics, chemistry, and materials engineering. The range of technological applications of carbon nanostructures can be expanded using chemical functionalization. Functionalization increases the solubility of graphene and carbon nanotubes in organic solvents, opening a way for the synthesis of polymer nanocomposites. Covalent functionalization alters the electronic and transport properties of carbon nanomaterials, providing a basis for the development of molecular electronics.

This research project was focused on the development and applications of state-of-the-art computational methodologies to study the mechanism of chemical functionalization of carbon nanotubes, graphene, and graphene nanoribbons. The main objective of this research was the investigation of the relationship between the structural and electronic characteristics of carbon nanostructures and their reactivity toward organic and inorganic molecules and functional groups. The study was carried out by combining density functional and time-dependent density functional theoretical approaches with parallel computational algorithms optimized for Beowulf computer clusters. The research performed in the context of this project was concentrated on the following three areas: the study of the mechanism of doping and point defect formation in carbon nanostructures, the investigation of the structure-selective surface functionalization of graphene and carbon nanotubes, and the study of the effects of surface and edge functionalization on the electronic and transport properties of graphene nanoribbons.

Theoretical studies of carbon nanostructures carried out in the framework of this project have led to a better understanding of the process of self-assembly of molecules and functional groups on the surfaces of carbon nanotubes, graphene, and graphene nanoribbons. The knowledge gained from these studies is important for the development of new types of nanoscale materials that could be used in chemical sensors, fuel cells, organic light-emitting diodes, photovoltaic cells, and nanoelectronic devices. Computational models and algorithms developed in the course of this project can be applied to a wide range of nanoscale systems, including organic molecules, composite materials and polymers, nanocrystals, quantum dots, and nanowires. The results obtained from this research are expected to be beneficial for many areas of technology that utilize nanomaterials and employ complex computational algorithms, particularly nanotechnology, microelectronics, and information technology.

Broader impact and educational activities carried out in the context of this project included the development of a new graduate course, adding the elements of nanoscience and nanotechnology to the curriculum of undergraduate and graduate courses, and academic advising, training, and support of graduate students. The developed courses promoted the use of computers in the classroom and incorporated homework assignments involving advanced computer modeling and simulations. These contributions improved the quality of education and enhanced the learning experience of students enrolled in Physics and Engineering Physics programs at New Mexico State University. Three graduate students were directly involved in research related to this project. These students received training in computational chemistry, electronic structure methods, and computer programming. The research carried out in the context of this project formed the foundation of Ph.D. dissertations for these three students.
